reviews.title: Not recommended for year 1 freshman
reviews.comment_content: 如果你對政治或者political philosophy有興趣嘅話，可以試吓take依個course。內容會由Social Contract Theory講到separation of powers, political parties, etc. 我覺得overall幾有趣嘅，不過始終係sosci科，有啲哲學嘢屬於humanities (例如Social contract theory等等)，所以professor又冇乜特別講得好深入，所以如果你對依方面有興趣多啲，我建議你唔好take 依科sosc。Btw依個course都着重discussion(每堂我諗有1/4時間會係Q&A)，而discussion對依科幾重要，所以都有可能幾political sensitive(你懂的)而唔俾recording同埋淨係得f2f lecture嗰啲嘅，所以就留意吓，個人唔排除之後會冇依科嘅可能性。
reviews.comment_teaching:
上堂基本上會成日答問題，好多互動，上堂前會播吓同嗰堂有關嘅歌（例如講legitimacy會播N.W.A（咩歌就自己諗啦））
不過語速偏快同用字唔算易明，所以local學生就有啲輸蝕，但基本上唔上堂淨係睇lecture notes都明嘅。
reviews.comment_grading:
内容有趣，但grading唔算特別好。
作為一個year 1 fm同英文差嘅學生，你要競爭嘅係有啲外國人同senior(幾多)，所以建議senior先take依科。
每堂會有reading materials俾你去prepare嗰堂lecture嘅，而每個禮拜會有一次mini-exam (4% *10次)。基本上你每堂有睇吓啲notes都足夠攞mean，但建議如果aim high，有唔明就問ta/prof，或者上網睇多啲資料(例如哲學有計傾講J.S.Mill/其他)，會幫到你了解得更深入。
Overall 算above mean，不過得B-，主要係份memo啲groupmate做得幾垃圾又唔準時跟internal deadline，最尾拉低哂個grade dllm :)記得揾班好groupmate，最好carry到你
reviews.comment_workload: 其實唔算多，如果你唔睇佢啲reading materials嘅話基本上幾chill，不過睇嘅話每次廿零三十版又長又悶又難明又深嘅reading都幾重workload，不過反正又唔係compulsory所以workload真係幾低。最多都係要你重温啲notes嚟prepare mini-exams(Mini-exams *10次, 40%)、做memo (30%)、睇新聞（concepts related to your memo topic, you can just write a few sentences and get a full mark, 10%)、suggesting exam questions (10%)、participation (10%)同5% bonus。

reviews.author: Paolo
reviews.title: Easy CC course if you love politics
reviews.comment_content:
DISCLAIMER: this course doesn't talk about world events, it talks about fundamental concepts of politics.

The content is divided into two groups:
Group #1: 1Political Theory
Ch1 - Politics
Ch2 - States and Power
Ch3 - Democracy and Obligation
Ch4 - Freedom and Justice
Ch5 - Ideologies

Group #2: Comparative Politics
Ch6 - Constitutions
Ch7 - Elections
Ch8 - Political Parties
Ch9 - Government
Ch10 - Society
Ch11 - Regimes

Group 1 is self explanatory, it's about theories like how these terms are defined and conceptualised by different political philosophers.
Group 2 on the other hand talks more about political systems that is present in the real world.

Honestly, the content aren't difficult to understand. You might have different expectations when you enrolled, i know i have, but it won't be a problem.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is great. Because it's a summer class and each session is 3 hours long, James Wong would usually give a 5 minute break after every hour. He speaks at an appropriate pace, and most of his words are just elaborations of whats already in the PPT to help you understand.

He also made the lecture more interactive, event though it's difficult through zoom. That includes asking questions, discussion breakout rooms, games, and polls. In my opinion, it was fun.
reviews.comment_grading:
Its a bit different this year, because of the wuhan pneumonia pandemic, James Wong give us two Essays and assignments to grade us instead of exams.

Assignments: 30%
Essay 1 and 2: 70%

Jame Wong's grading is very generous. Scoring 0.5 SD above mean for both essays is enough to secure "A" range. And the assignments are very easy. I got an A- grade in this course
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments:
•3 open-book quizzes
•2 social media posts (basically a short essay in a social media post format, about any real world event and applying what you learn from this course)
both assignments need to submit 1 day later

Essays 1 and 2:
•1000 max word analytical/argumentative essay on one of the 5 questions given. 3 days to complete

Overall the workload is quite low. It might take some time to absorb and understand James Wong's lectures, but the assignments are very easy. It will take 1 day at most to finish the essay assuming you understand his lectures.

In Comparative Politics, topics about Law and Constitutions; Voting, Elections, and Political Parties; Government Systems;
Civil Society Actors; Political Regimes will be introduced.

Since the whole course mainly talk about different theories and concepts in political  science, it will be quite boring if you have no passion in studying political science.

For the summer term, usually, we covered a new topic every lecture.
These are the topics covered in 2022 summer term:
Class 1: Orientation
Class 2: The state
Class 3: Political Power
class 4: democracy
class 5: Freedom and Justice

The content of the course is not difficult, little to no knowledge about politics is required to follow through the lectures.

reviews.title: Mediocre at best
reviews.comment_content:
Writing this review from the point of view of someone who is interested in politics, for perhaps obvious reasons.

The concepts and ideas in this course are basic, like the state, democracy and such, however, there is a deeper emphasis on the practical aspects of politics, such as gerrymandering, political parties and so on, which were frankly quite boring, if you expect ideas like political ideologies and philosophy, prepared to be disappointed.

Overall the course does give you a working knowledge of political science, but not very deep as this is a common core course, register if you are interested in the practical side of politics, instead of the theoretical side.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was only OK, professor Keller explained her ideas clearly, with good examples to illustrate the points, powerpoints are simple but made well and clear which helps a lot with studying for the quizzes. Lectures are mandatory because there are both in class quizzes on readings and mini exams on lecture contents.

Personally speaking it was a bit boring but that has more to do with the course content, not the teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mini-exams: 30%
10 exams in total, each covering 2 lectures worth of content, quite easy and if you have read the readings and looked at the powerpoint even just a little bit before the exam you can do well.

Suggesting exam questions: 10%
Suggest 2 questions that may be used in the mini-exams, questions were based on the course content of the week.

In-class participation: 10%
As the name suggests, just be active in the chat and talk more, despite being worth 10% the chat is surprisingly inactive.

News: 10%
At the beginning of the semester you are asked to choose 3 countries that you will research the politics on, and after that you find 2 articles from the news media in that country that relates to the course content.

Presentation: 20%
Make a 10 minute video discussing the most important political question in the country you are assigned to, work in groups of 6.

Memo on the government of your choice: 20%
1 page long memo of the aforementioned presentation, needs to include feedback given by the professor.

Bonus: 5%
in-class quizzes based on the readings.

Mean marks:
mini-exams: 21/30%
suggesting exam questions: 8/10%
news: 8.73/10%
participation: 9.03/10%
presentation: 16/20%
memo: 17.9/20%
Bonus: 3.3/5%

With these EXTREMELY high means given by the lenience of the grading, EVERY little percent matters, therefore if you aim for a good grade, you MUST do well on the bonus, study for the mini-exams, and be active in chat, and most importantly pray to whatever religious figure that you get good groupmates.

God was not on my side, giving me quite incompetent groupmates, meaning that I got below mean in both the memo and the presentation, but because the grading is so lenient, it is only -2% in the final grade, as I performed well in other areas, I ended up with a 91.6/100%, 8% higher than the mean, netting me a grade of A-, which was on the poor side as I expected an A...
reviews.comment_workload:
Rated at B, but is actually B- to a C+ as workload is heavy for a common core, 1000-level course.

Readings are necessary if you want the 5% bonus marks, and instead of interesting, political philosophy that you may expect and want from a course titled "politics", the actual readings are quite boring, and often focus on the details and statistics. There are a few good readings, such as Mill, Montesquieu and so on, but most are quite boring. Most people seem to not read them aswell. Meaning you could get an advantage over others for very little work, even if its 1-2% over grades.

As for the mini-exams, they are quite easy and only takes around half an hour or so of studying to do well in, since each exam covers 2 lectures.

On group projects, working in groups of 6 means that you have to work with others, and cannot "carry" the entire group given that its a 10 minute long presentation. That means you are simply at the mercy of the competence of your groupmates, if you get bad groupmates who don't help, this will be quite difficult as you either have to suffer a bad grade, OR help them fix their poorly made parts. This applies to both the memo AND the presentation (40% of grade!), so workload could fluctuate greatly depending on your luck.

News and suggesting exam questions: just 15 minutes per week going on news sites or looking at notes to think of a question, not hard.

Again, this course focuses more on the practical side of politics, if you are interested in politics as in the philosophy (or more relevant to the current situation), look elsewhere such as SOSC1661, or if you want to have a better time studying this, wait until James is teaching that semester.

I guess it is more important for students to show their understanding towards the topics and try to make use of the evidence and examples they have observed in the real world (i.e. not just analysing and rephrasing the theories which have been explained super clearly in the lessons). For the essays, maybe students should be more careful about their writing styles and the organisation of the work.
reviews.comment_workload: Acceptable (requirements and grading can be found on the left hand side), you can finish all the assignments quickly as long as you have paid attention to what the prof. said in the lessons, part of the answers can even be directly found in the lecture notes (but don't forget to rephrase the sentences).

reviews.comment_content:
This course introduces some basic concepts and theories in political science. Topics include:
- Political theory: politics and the state, power and authority, social contract theory, forms of democracy, freedom and justice
- Comparative politics: institutions, judiciary, legislature, executive, political parties, civil society
- International relations

*The actual progress this semester was affected for a bit due to the Professor's absence and school suspension. The International Relations part was omitted.

The textbook (although it will not be examined) is also a good source of knowledge if you want to learn something outside of the lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She explained the concepts with quite a lot of examples. I especially appreciate it when she included texts that are related to politics written by prominent scholars as readings (like Max Weber, Adam Przeworski, John Stuart Mill and Benedict Anderson). They may be quite difficult, but they provide insight. Prof. would explain them after the iPRS questions are raised.

Sometimes the progress in lessons gets a little too slow as there are quite a lot of iPRS questions and loads of enquiries raised by classmates, which she had to carry the previous theme into the next lecture and cut down the content.

She really welcomes questions though, and she would reply to anything being asked in lectures or on the CANVAS discussion board.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Mid-term exam (25%)
2. Final exam (40%)
3. iPRS (attendance) (10%)
4. Bonus points for answering an iPRS question correctly or raising questions in class (+5%)
5. Presentation on one country of your choice (20%):
6. Relating concepts to events (news articles) in one country of your choice (5%)

*Due to special circumstances this semester, an alternate marking scheme is applied if one chooses not to sit for the final exam (I chose this grading option):
Mid-term (41.6%) --> 87/114, Mean: 69.1
Attendance (16.6%) --> 12/12
News articles (8.3%) --> 12/12
Group project (33.3%) --> Presentation: 19/20; Memo: 20/20
Bonus (+5%) --> 3.3/5

The distribution chart shown to us after the midterm puts certain ranges of marks into different letter grades. So I guess she is using absolute grading.

Though the tentative grade released is an A, my actual grade turned out to be an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Comprehending the readings do take up a lot of time, especially if you want to gain bonus points from the iPRS questions. Though some of them can be guessed based on logic.

The newspaper part is easy. You can choose newspapers or news articles from any time, just relate it to the chosen concept with one or two sentences is okay. (I just simply summarized the articles)

The project is not too difficult either. Just make sure you have responsible groupmates.

The exam is straightforward (just recalling concepts and definitions), combining T/F questions and short questions. Remember to jot down the iPRS questions, it would be useful for the exam as it includes the essence of the readings. Some content that is not explicitly mentioned in the ppt can also be tested, so note down what the Prof. says.

reviews.comment_content:
This course introduces students to two main fields of political studies – political theory and comparative politics. Political theory looks at the normative world of politics, seeking to evaluate and recommend political arrangements through the study of concepts and ideologies. Comparative politics looks at the empirical world of politics, seeking to understand and explain political phenomena through the study of actors, institutions, and their dynamics. Students benefit from the analytical knowledge and skills as well as the political sense and awareness for surviving in a ‘politicized’ world.
